title: Fast Global Registration

Another point set that also covers this object partially.
It's also incomplete.
It's also noisy and it covers a different part of this object.
And now consider that you get these two points in completely different coordinate systems.
You don't know how they fit you.
Don't know how they align and your goal is to align them.
This is the problem of global registration.
It's encountered in many settings in robotics, computer graphics, an 3D vision.
In particular, we often need to do this to reconstruct the unknown object scene or map that is partially imaged by a 3D image Ng device.
I will now.
Review a basic algorithm, a basic component that's used inside many global registration pipelines.
This is why of interest of introducing our new algorithm and how it differs.
So let's take the iterative closest points algorithm, AICP, perhaps the best known algorithm in registration, and perhaps in geometry processing as a whole.
I see does not solve the global registration problem that I posed because it needs an initialization.
It needs these two point sets to be approximately aligned to begin with.
When you get these two point sets that are almost aligned, icy computes nearest neighbors across the two point sets.
It takes these nearest neighbor correspondences and minimizes distances between these corresponding pairs.

Now that we changed the pose to bring the corresponding pairs as close as possible together, the nearest neighbors may have changed, so we recompute.
Nearest neighbors, this establishes different correspondence pairs and we iterate.
We again minimize distances.
Between these corresponding pairs and we go on like this, iterating changing the correspondence pairs using nearest neighbor search an, bringing them together for as many iterations as we want.
To do global registration, you can first get a course alignment by a fairly brute force sampling based scheme such as ransack, sawran.
Second similar schemes.
Just sample couples of points using some heuristics an see if the alignment induced by this simple tuple is good and we repeat this until we get a tuple that's good.
The course alignment.
This initial alignment induced by this tuple is fine, and then we run any CP for local refinement.
So we have two stages here.
Course alignment and local refinement.

Perhaps surprisingly, this two stage scheme in practice is the best current approach to global registration, as we and others have discovered, in practice with big data, real data produced by noisy depth cameras and other 3D imaging devices on the large scale, this scheme of works as well as any other, despite a tremendous amount of work on this problem, and this two stage scheme that I just presented.
Is used at the very core of high Fidelity scenery.
Construction pipelines such as the pipeline that we presented at CPR last year.
It is, however, deeply dissatisfying.
First, it's computationally expensive.
Their nearest neighbor queries in the inner loop in each of the two stages, thousands and thousands of times we need to traverse spatial data structures to find nearest neighbor pairs.
This is in the inner loop, and it slows down both stages of the pipeline.

Is in itself dissatisfying.
It seems inelegant.

This algorithm works as well as the best performing prior, geometric registration, global geometric registration pipeline when there is a lot of noise, our algorithm works much better in has two times higher.
Accuracy on average than the best than the most accurate prior global pipeline an the maximal error on this data set is more than five times lower by our algorithm.
Perhaps even more exciting is that this algorithm is 50 times faster on this data set than the fastest prior global registration method.
Now let's compare to local algorithms such as the famous AICP algorithm.

That means that the error of the AICP algorithms D increases, so the AICP algorithms progressively breakdown when you initialize them farther and farther away from the ground truth pose.
Our algorithm is the flat line at the bottom that looks like the horizontal axis.

It's completely insensitive to the initialization, but it gets the accuracy that AICP gets when it's initialized near the ground truth pose, so our algorithm doesn't need an initialization, but it gives you the accuracy that I see gives you when it's initialized by the ground truth pose.
Furthermore, our algorithm is faster on this data set.
Our global algorithm that doesn't need an initialization is about 3 times faster than AICP, which does.

The correspondences are never re computed.

The correspondences, whereas we never do this.

It's more than an order of magnitude faster than the prior global registration algorithms an it either matches or exceeds their accuracy, particularly when there is noise in the data and fairly surprisingly it matches the accuracy of icy style algorithms which need an initialization.
Without needing an initialization an, it's faster.
